news:

**Pennsylvania-based cheese company recalls products due to potential Listeria contamination**
Savencia Cheese, a Lancaster County-based company, is recalling its select soft-ripened cheeses due to a potential Listeria monocytogenes contamination. According to the FDA, routine tests identified possible listeria contamination on the factory's processing equipment. Although there have been no reports of health issues among customers, the FDA is recalling all products involved. Customers can identify the affected products by the best buy date or UPC numbers, which are carried by retailers such as Aldi and La Bonne Vie.

**Major supermarket issues urgent recall of pasta favourite**
Co-op supermarket is recalling its own-brand Irresistible Luxury Lasagne Al Forno due to possible health risks. The affected batches, with a best before date of November 17, 2024, may contain mustard and sulphites, which were not listed on the label. The Food Standards Agency (FSA) warns that the product is 'unsafe to eat' for those with life-threatening allergies to mustard or sensitivities to sulphur dioxide or sulphites. Customers who have purchased the affected product are eligible for a refund or replacement, and the Co-op has contacted allergy support organisations to inform their members. The FSA advises those with allergies or sensitivities to dispose of the product and not consume it. 'If you have bought the above product and have an allergy to mustard and/or a sensitivity to sulphur dioxide and/or sulphites do not consume it. Instead, dispose of the product,' the FSA warns.

**Savencia Cheese recalls Brie cheeses sold at Aldi, Market Basket after listeria concerns**
Savencia Cheese USA has voluntarily recalled six types of Brie cheese due to potential listeria concerns. The recall affects products with a 'best by' date of December 24, 2024, and was initiated after listeria monocytogenes was identified in the processing equipment at the manufacturing plant. The FDA has stated that there have been no confirmed reports of illness or death due to the consumption of the recalled products. Consumers are advised to check the best by date and UPC to determine if their product is affected and to return it to the place of purchase for a full refund. 'Consumers that have any of the recalled products listed in the table above should refrain from consuming them and return them to their place of purchase for a full refund,' the FDA said. According to the USDA, listeria can cause serious illness in immunocompromised individuals, young children, older individuals, and pregnant people, and can be fatal in some cases. An estimated 1,600 people get listeriosis each year and an estimated 260 die in the U.S. each year.

**BrucePac Recalls 10 Million Pounds of Ready-to-Eat Food Products Due to Listeria Risk**
BrucePac, a manufacturer of pre-cooked meat and poultry, has recalled nearly 10 million pounds of ready-to-eat food products due to a Listeria risk. The products were sold at major retailers such as Trader Joe's, Wegmans, 7-Eleven, Kroger, and others. The recall affects mainly pre-made salads, burritos, and wraps with chicken. According to the US Department of Agriculture, the contamination was caused by pre-cooked chicken from the Oklahoma-based company. BrucePac has since provided further information and updates on specific affected products. The list of recalled items consists mainly of pre-made salads, burritos, and wraps with chicken, sometimes combined with other meat types such as bacon or ham. The products were produced from June 19 to October 8. Most of the products have expired, but some frozen meals from brands like Jenny Craig and Michelina's are still good until 2025 or 2026. Additional retailers that may have sold potentially contaminated products include Walmart, Meijer, Giant Eagle, Amazon, Target, and Aldi, as well as some gas stations and corner stores. No illnesses or deaths have been reported in connection with BrucePac meat. The US Department of Agriculture advises consumers to discard or return any recalled products they may have, and not to sell any remaining products that may be affected. BrucePac did not indicate whether consumers would be eligible for refunds or discounts. The company did not respond to a request for comment. On its website, BrucePac wrote: 'We are committed to providing safe and high-quality products. We work closely with the USDA to ensure that all necessary measures are taken to ensure a safe food supply. We will resume production only when we are certain that the problem has been resolved.'

Consumers are urged to check the labels of ready-to-eat meat or poultry products they may have in their possession or see on store shelves for the establishment numbers '51205 or P-51205' within or beneath the USDA mark of inspection. The USDA is advising all restaurants, institutions, stores, and establishments not to serve, use, or sell the recalled products, and to throw them away or return them to wherever they were purchased. Consumers should also throw away or return any recalled product they have in their possession. According to the USDA, Listeriosis can cause symptoms including fever, muscle aches, headache, stiff neck, confusion, loss of balance, and convulsions, and can be treated with antibiotics. However, the infection can be more serious in older adults and people with weakened immune systems, and can be life-threatening for pregnant women and newborn babies.

question_title: Will Noodles & Co. file for bankruptcy before January 1, 2025?
news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Iconic casual restaurant chain files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy**
The restaurant sector has struggled in 2024 due to the lingering effects of the Covid-19 pandemic, rising costs, and consumers becoming more discerning about their dining choices. Several restaurant chains have closed underperforming locations or filed for bankruptcy protection, including Red Lobster, BurgerFi International, EYM Pizza, and Arby's franchisee Miracle Restaurant Group. TGI Fridays, a popular casual dining chain, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy on November 2, citing financial distress caused by the pandemic, inflation, and rising costs. The company listed $100 million to $500 million in assets and liabilities and is seeking approval of up to $23.9 million in debtor-in-possession financing to fund its operations and bankruptcy case. According to Chief Restructuring Officer Kyle Richter, the company's financial distress was caused by the lingering effects of the pandemic, a volatile macroeconomic environment, global inflation, significant interest rate increases, and rising costs.
Original language: en
Publish date: November 05, 2024 12:19 AM
Source:[Post and Courier](https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/finance/iconic-casual-restaurant-chain-files-for-chapter-11-bankruptcy/article_f501b639-a8af-576b-9f4f-54abb6d38bbd.html)

**TGI Fridays files for bankruptcy protection, becoming latest restaurant chain to falter**
TGI Fridays, the American casual restaurant chain, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection due to a flawed capital structure and rising everyday prices. The company has been quietly closing locations since January and has secured financing to keep its 39 company-owned locations open during bankruptcy. Executive Chairman Rohit Manocha stated, 'The next steps announced today are difficult but necessary actions to protect the best interests of our stakeholders.' The company plans to use its bankruptcy protection to explore strategic alternatives and ensure the long-term viability of the brand. This move is part of a larger trend affecting American casual restaurant chains such as Red Lobster and Denny's, as middle-class consumers cut back on discretionary spending and high prices squeeze profits.
Original language: en
Publish date: November 04, 2024 10:10 PM
Source:[biztoc.com](https://www.latimes.com/business/story/2024-11-04/tgi-fridays-files-for-bankruptcy-the-latest-restaurant-chain-to-falter?ref=biztoc.com)

**It's Official: TGI Fridays Files for Bankruptcy, Cites Pandemic Among Financial Challenges**
TGI Fridays, the American casual dining chain, has filed for bankruptcy due to financial challenges caused by the pandemic and an overextended capital structure. The company, which owns 39 domestic restaurants, reported assets and liabilities between $100 million and $500 million. A recent Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) study found low mandatory vaccine rates among U.S. healthcare workers. A recent study found that only 11% of 'flu' cases are caused by the influenza virus, which raises questions about the effectiveness of flu vaccines. It also warns that the global AI divide, where frontier AI research and development primarily occurs in Western countries, will exacerbate inequalities between nations. The report concludes that the capabilities of general-purpose AI are advancing rapidly, but there is limited understanding of the capabilities and inner workings of these systems, especially as they are suited to generate external harms.
